Polynomial Division

Factorising large numbers can make them simpler to understand, and the same thing is true with polynomials:

Expanded form  Factorised form
\(3417652\)  =  \(2^2\cdot7^3\cdot47\cdot53\)  
  \(x^3+3x^2-6x-8\)    =\( (x+1)(x-2)(x+4) \)

A key tool we use when factorising numbers is division (e.g. we spot that 2 is a factor, then divide by 2 to see what the other factor is), so we need to be able to do this with polynomials too.


Dividing numbers is familiar, but recall that it is based on facts about multiplication, e.g. \[ 4\times3=12 \qquad \text{so} \qquad \dfrac{12}{3}=4\]

We can do the same sort of thing with polynomials, e.g.

\[ (x+4)(x-3)=x^2+x-12 \qquad \text{so} \qquad \dfrac{x^2+x-12}{x-3}=x+4. \]

Recall that if the numbers don't divide exactly we will get a "remainder", e.g. \[ \dfrac{13}{3}=\dfrac{12+1}{3}=\dfrac{12}{3}+\dfrac{1}{3}=4+\dfrac13 \quad  \text{i.e. }\unicode{x201C}\text{4 remainder 1''} \] We can use a similar process with polynomials.

A function which is the division of two polynomials is called a rational function, e.g. \[ \frac{x^2+x+1}{x-5}, \qquad \frac{x^3+x+1}{x-2} \qquad \frac{x^5+x^3=5x^2+1}{x^2+3} \] are all rational functions. Often dividing a polynomial \(P(x)\) by another is only useful if the degree of the denominator is less than or equal to the degree of the numerator.


Example

Divide the polynomial \(2x^3 + 7x^2 + 10x +15\) by \(x+2\).

Solution

Note that \(2x^3 + 7x^2 + 10x +15 = (2x^2 +3x+4)(x+2)+7\). So, to divide by \(x+2\) we have \[ \begin{align*} \frac{2x^3 + 7x^2 + 10x +15}{x+2} &= \frac{(2x^2 +3x+4)(x+2)+7}{x+2} \\ &= \frac{(2x^2 +3x+4)(x+2)}{x+2} + \frac{7}{x+2} \\ &= 2x^2 +3x+4 + \frac{7}{x+2}. \end{align*} \] We have now successfully performed the division, notice that the fraction \(\frac{7}{x+2}\) tells us that \(7\) is the remainder on performing this division. We can use this example to say something more generally about dividing by linear functions.


If the polynomial \(P(x)\) is divided by the linear function \(ax+b\) until a constant remainder \(r\) is obtained then \[ \frac{P(x)}{ax+b} = Q(x)+\frac{r}{ax+b}. \] Here, we call \(ax + b\) the divisor and it is often denoted \(D(x)\), \(Q(x)\) is called the quotient and \(r\) is the remainder. Notice that \(P(x) = Q(x) \cdot (ax+b) + r\).
